text: Make sure you go somewhere where you have a good engineering partner. Because if you have great ideas of what to build but you can't get them built, then you go nowhere. So that has to be part of your evaluation criteria that you meet and value your engineering partner before you join. And then I think what's really important is that you're aligned. You understand your roles and responsibilities and where you're going to divide and conquer and where you're going to be aligned. You don't want any of this ... Like people in the organization, they ask mom, they asked dad and they got different opinions and playing one against the other. That doesn't work.
speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
context: Lenny asks Tamar about building stronger cross-functional relationships, especially between product managers and engineers. Tamar explains that having a strong engineering partnership is crucial for product success - great ideas mean nothing if they can't be executed. She emphasizes the importance of alignment between product and engineering leaders, where both parties understand their roles and responsibilities and don't undermine each other by giving conflicting direction to their teams.
text_ko: 반드시 좋은 엔지니어링 파트너(engineering partner)가 있는 곳으로 가세요. 뭘 만들어야 할지 좋은 아이디어가 있어도 그걸 실제로 만들지 못하면 아무 진전이 없어요. 그래서 합류하기 전에 엔지니어링 파트너를 직접 만나보고 그들을 존중하고 함께 일할 수 있는지를 평가 기준에 꼭 넣으세요. 그리고 정말 중요한 건 방향성이 맞는다는 거예요. 서로의 역할과 책임(roles and responsibilities)을 분명히 이해하고, 어떤 부분을 누가 맡아 처리할지(divide and conquer)와 어디서 함께할지를 명확히 해야 해요. 조직에서 누구한테 물어보느냐에 따라 다른 답을 받고, 그걸로 사람들을 편가르기하듯 이용하는 방식은 잘 안 통해요.
text_zh: 一定要确保你找到一个靠谱的技术合作伙伴。因为你有再好的想法，如果做不出来，那就是白搭。所以在你加入之前，这必须是你考量的标准之一——要先了解和认可你的技术合伙人。然后我觉得特别重要的是，你们要步调一致。要清楚各自的职责分工，哪些事情分头干，哪些事情要统一行动。千万别出现那种...就像组织里的人，今天问妈妈，明天问爸爸，得到不同的答案，然后挑拨离间。这样肯定不行。
text_es: Asegúrate de ir a un lugar donde tengas un buen socio de ingeniería. Porque si tienes ideas geniales de qué construir pero no logras que se hagan realidad, no llegas a ningún lado. Entonces eso tiene que ser parte de tus criterios de evaluación: que conozcas y valores a tu socio de ingeniería antes de unirte. Y después creo que lo que es súper importante es que estén alineados. Que entiendan sus roles y responsabilidades, dónde van a dividirse las tareas y dónde van a trabajar juntos. No quieres nada de esto de... Como cuando la gente en la organización le pregunta a mamá, luego le pregunta a papá, obtienen opiniones diferentes y ponen a uno contra el otro. Eso no funciona.
key_sentence: Value your engineering partner as part of your evaluation criteria.

text: One of the things that I think is overlooked is do a really good job at whatever your job is at that point. People have a tendency ... Especially product managers are very ambitious and they want to get to the next level and they're always eyeing the next job, but you're not going to get the next job unless you do really well at the job that you're in. Knock it out of the park. However simple, however easy it may be to you, do a great job.
speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
context: Lenny asks Tamar about the specific skills or habits that contributed most to her successful career. Tamar explains that one of the most overlooked but important factors is excelling at your current role rather than constantly focusing on the next promotion. She argues that ambitious product managers often make the mistake of always looking ahead instead of delivering exceptional results in their present position, which is actually the key to advancement.
vocabulary_highlights: knock it out of the park
text_ko: 제가 간과된다고 생각하는 것 중 하나는, 그 순간 맡은 일을 정말 잘하는 거예요. 사람들은 특히 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)들이 야망이 커서 항상 다음 단계만 보고 다음 직책을 노리는 경향이 있어요. 그런데 지금 하는 일을 정말 잘하지 않으면 다음 자리를 못 잡아요. 지금 맡은 일을 기대 이상으로, 완전히 해내세요. 아무리 단순하고 쉬워 보여도 훌륭하게 해내는 게 중요해요.
text_zh: 我觉得大家容易忽略的一点就是，先把手头的工作做到位。很多人都有这个毛病……特别是产品经理(product manager)，野心都挺大，总想着升职加薪，眼睛老盯着下一个岗位，但问题是你现在这个活儿都没干好，凭什么给你升职？得先把现在的工作做得漂漂亮亮的。不管这事儿在你看来多简单多容易，都要做到最好。
text_es: Una de las cosas que creo que se pasa por alto es hacer un trabajo excelente en lo que sea que estés haciendo en ese momento. La gente tiene tendencia... Especialmente los product managers son muy ambiciosos y quieren llegar al siguiente nivel y siempre están mirando el próximo puesto, pero no vas a conseguir el siguiente trabajo si no haces muy bien el trabajo que tienes ahora. Tienes que romperla completamente. Por más simple que sea, por más fácil que te parezca, haz un trabajo increíble.
key_sentence: Knock it out of the park to advance your career.

text: One of the things that I caution product managers about is that you don't want to be too overly reliant on metrics and you want to also have an intuition. You want product managers who understand intuitively their customers and their product and sometimes you'll make decisions because you just know it's the right thing to do because it feels right and it usually is right if you understand your product well enough.
speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
context: Lenny asks for an example of understanding people in product development. Tamar discusses the balance between data-driven decisions and product intuition. She explains that while metrics are important, product managers shouldn't rely on them exclusively - they need to develop intuitive understanding of their customers and products. This intuition, when properly developed through deep product knowledge, can guide correct decisions even when data might not provide clear direction.
text_ko: 제가 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)들에게 자주 주의시키는 것 중 하나는 지표(metrics)에만 지나치게 의존하지 말라는 거예요. 직관(intuition)도 있어야 해요. 고객과 제품을 직관적으로 이해하는 프로덕트 매니저가 필요하고, 때로는 그냥 옳게 느껴져서 결정을 내릴 때도 있는데, 제품을 충분히 이해하고 있으면 그런 선택이 보통 맞는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 我经常提醒产品经理的一点就是，不要过分依赖数据指标，还得有直觉。你要找那种对客户和产品有直觉的产品经理，有时候做决策就是凭感觉，觉得这么做是对的就去做，如果你对产品足够了解的话，这种感觉通常都是准的。
text_es: Una de las cosas sobre las que les advierto a los product managers es que no se pueden apoyar demasiado en las métricas nada más, también tienen que tener intuición. Necesitas product managers que entiendan de forma intuitiva a sus clientes y su producto, y a veces vas a tomar decisiones simplemente porque sabes que es lo correcto, porque lo sientes así, y por lo general sí es lo correcto si conoces tu producto lo suficientemente bien.
key_sentence: Don't be overly reliant on metrics; trust your intuition.

text: I love working at well-run companies. It's more fun, your people are happier. I like running a well-run team, so I aspire to have a very well run team and to work at a well run company. But what I've seen is when a company isn't well run like IT isn't working, marketing is broken, there are not enough people in HR, there's a lot of turnover. All of these things I've seen that they're not correlated to the company being successful.
speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
context: Lenny asks about Tamar's insight that companies don't need to be well-run to win. Tamar explains this seemingly contrarian view by distinguishing between what makes companies pleasant to work at versus what makes them successful. She acknowledges preferring well-run organizations for personal satisfaction, but observes that operational dysfunction - like broken IT systems, poor marketing, inadequate HR, and high turnover - doesn't necessarily prevent business success, while she's also seen well-run companies that fail to grow.
text_ko: 저는 잘 운영되는 회사에서 일하는 걸 정말 좋아해요. 일이 더 즐겁고 직원들도 더 행복하거든요. 저는 체계적으로 잘 돌아가는 팀을 이끄는 걸 좋아해서, 그런 팀을 만들고 그런 회사에서 일하는 걸 목표로 해요. 그런데 제가 본 바로는 회사가 제대로 운영되지 않을 때—예를 들어 정보기술(IT)이 안 돌아가거나 마케팅(marketing)에 문제가 있거나 인사(HR) 인력이 부족하거나 이직률이 높다든지—이런 문제들이 회사의 성공 여부와는 크게 상관없더라고요.
text_zh: 我特别喜欢在管理到位的公司工作，这样工作起来更有意思，团队里的人也更开心。我自己也喜欢带一支运转良好的团队，所以我的目标就是要有一个管理很棒的团队，也要在一个管理很棒的公司工作。但我发现的是，当一个公司管理不善的时候，比如IT系统老出问题，市场部一团糟，HR人手不够，员工流失率很高，我见过很多这种情况，但这些问题其实跟公司是否成功没有直接关系。
text_es: Me encanta trabajar en empresas que están bien organizadas. Es más divertido, la gente está más contenta. Me gusta dirigir un equipo que funcione bien, así que aspiro a tener un equipo súper bien organizado y trabajar en una empresa que esté bien llevada. Pero lo que he visto es que cuando una empresa no está bien manejada - como que TI no funciona, marketing está hecho un desastre, no hay suficiente gente en Recursos Humanos, hay mucha rotación de personal - todas estas cosas que he observado no tienen que ver con que la empresa sea exitosa.
key_sentence: I aspire to work at well-run companies, as they correlate with happiness.

text: Really recently I was talking to somebody in their twenties who was asking me for career advice. Should I be a product manager, et cetera. And I'm trying to put together my five-year plan and I said, 'I never had a five-year plan.' So to be clear, some people need that. That's the kind of people they are. They want the planning. I said, 'It's great if you want that, but I never had it.' And the person I was talking to just relaxed and they're like, 'Oh my God, that's so great to hear because I have no idea what I want to do in five years.' I'm like, 'I still have no idea what I want to do in five years. I've never had an idea what I want to do in five years.'
speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
context: Lenny asks about Tamar's belief that you don't need to plan your career. Tamar shares a recent conversation with someone in their twenties seeking career advice about becoming a product manager and creating a five-year plan. She reveals that she has never had a five-year career plan throughout her successful career, which immediately relieved the anxiety of the person she was advising. This challenges the conventional wisdom that successful careers require detailed long-term planning.
text_ko: 얼마 전에 20대인 분이랑 얘기했어요. 커리어 조언을 구하시더라고요. “프로덕트 매니저(product manager)를 할까, 뭐 이렇게…” 그리고 5년 플랜을 세우려고 하는데 어떻게 할지 고민한다고 해서 제가 말했어요. “저는 한 번도 5년 계획을 세워본 적이 없어요.” 분명히 말하면 어떤 사람들은 그게 필요해요. 그런 타입이고 계획 세우는 걸 좋아하죠. “그게 원하면 하는 게 좋아요, 근데 저는 그런 계획이 없었어요”라고 했더니 그분이 갑자기 마음이 편해지면서 “와, 그 말 들으니 진짜 좋네요. 저도 5년 후에 뭘 하고 싶은지 전혀 모르겠어요”라고 하더라고요. 그래서 저도 “저도 여전히 5년 후에 뭘 하고 싶은지 모르겠어요. 한 번도 그런 생각을 해본 적이 없어요”라고 했어요.
text_zh: 最近我跟一个二十多岁的人聊天，他问我职业建议。说是应该做产品经理(product manager)什么的。然后他说正在搞五年规划，我就说，'我从来没做过什么五年规划。'当然啊，有些人确实需要这个，这就是他们的性格，喜欢做规划。我说，'你要是喜欢做规划那挺好的，但我从来不做。'然后那个人一下子就放松了，说，'天哪，你这么说我心里踏实多了，因为我根本不知道五年后想干什么。'我说，'我现在还是不知道五年后想干什么呢。我从来就没想过五年后要干什么。'
text_es: Hace poquito estaba hablando con alguien de veintitantos que me pidió consejos profesionales. Que si debería ser product manager, y esas cosas. Y me dice, 'Estoy tratando de armar mi plan a cinco años' y le digo, 'Yo nunca tuve un plan a cinco años.' O sea, que quede claro, hay gente que lo necesita. Es su forma de ser. Les gusta planificar. Le dije, 'Está genial si es lo tuyo, pero yo nunca lo tuve.' Y la persona se relajó completamente y me dice, 'Ay, qué alivio escuchar eso porque no tengo ni idea de qué quiero hacer en cinco años.' Y le digo, 'Yo tampoco tengo ni idea de qué quiero hacer en cinco años. Nunca he tenido ni idea de qué quiero hacer en cinco años.'
key_sentence: I never had a five-year plan, and that's okay.

text: What I believe, and I've always believed is that you follow people. You learn the most from people. I don't look for domains. Some people have a domain, like I'm super interested in climate or whatever and they really want to work in that area and that's fine so maybe within that area. But you follow people who are the best at what they do. So it's not good enough to follow somebody who you like. You want to follow somebody who's either the best product thinker or the best engineer or the best salesperson. And so that you will learn the skill of how to be the best at that.
speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
context: Continuing the discussion about career planning, Tamar explains her philosophy for career progression without formal plans. Instead of focusing on specific industries or domains, she advocates following exceptional people - those who are genuinely the best at their craft, whether in product thinking, engineering, or sales. She emphasizes that personal likability isn't enough; you need to work with people who excel at their skills so you can learn how to become exceptional yourself.
text_ko: 제가 늘 믿어온 건 사람을 따라가야 한다는 거예요. 사람한테서 가장 많이 배우거든요. 저는 도메인(domain)을 찾지 않아요. 어떤 사람들은 기후 같은 특정 분야에 엄청 관심이 있어서 그 분야에서 일하고 싶어하는데, 그건 괜찮아요. 하지만 더 중요한 건 그 일을 가장 잘하는 사람을 따라가는 거예요. 단순히 좋아서 따라가는 것으로는 부족해요. 최고의 프로덕트 씽커(product thinker)나 최고의 엔지니어, 최고의 영업 담당자 같은 사람을 따라가야 그 분야에서 최고가 되는 법을 배우게 돼요.
text_zh: 我一直相信的是，你要跟对人。从人身上能学到最多东西。我不会专门去找什么行业领域。有些人确实对某个领域特别感兴趣，比如说特别想做气候相关的，想在那个领域深耕，这也没问题。但关键是你要跟那些在各自领域做得最牛的人。光是跟你喜欢的人混是不够的，你得跟那些要么是最顶尖的产品思维高手，要么是最牛的工程师，要么是最厉害的销售。这样你才能真正学会怎么在那个领域做到最好。
text_es: Lo que creo, y siempre he creído, es que hay que seguir a las personas. De la gente es de quien más aprendes. Yo no busco sectores específicos. Hay gente que tiene su sector, como "me interesa muchísimo el clima" o lo que sea, y realmente quieren trabajar en esa área, y está perfecto, entonces tal vez dentro de esa área. Pero tú sigues a las personas que son las mejores en lo que hacen. No basta con seguir a alguien que te cae bien. Quieres seguir a alguien que sea el mejor pensador de producto o el mejor ingeniero o el mejor vendedor. Así vas a aprender la habilidad de cómo ser el mejor en eso.
key_sentence: Follow people who are the best; it's not good enough to follow anyone else.

text: I got a piece of advice from a friend that I thought was amazing advice as a leader. She said to me, 'Take a job where if you hire people, it's going to make their careers.' I was like, 'Whoa.' Because I was getting offers for some turnaround jobs. And if you think you can turn around, great. But if you're going to hire the best people, you want to make sure that it's going to be a good place for them and that they're going to learn and they're going to grow.
speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
context: Lenny discusses the concept of companies having gravitational pull for talent. Tamar shares advice she received from a friend about leadership job selection. When she was considering various leadership roles, including some turnaround situations, her friend suggested she only take positions where hiring people would advance their careers. This advice made her realize she should evaluate opportunities not just for her own benefit, but for whether she could genuinely help the people she'd recruit to learn and grow.
text_ko: 친구한테서 들은 조언이 하나 있는데, 리더로서 정말 놀랍다고 생각했어요. 친구가 "사람을 뽑을 때 그들의 경력을 만들어줄 수 있는 직장을 선택해라"라고 하더라고요. 저는 '와' 했어요. 그때 저도 몇 군데 턴어라운드(turnaround) 자리 제안을 받고 있었거든요. 회사를 되살릴 수 있다고 생각한다면 그건 좋은 일이죠. 하지만 최고의 사람들을 뽑을 거라면, 그곳이 그들에게 좋은 자리인지, 배우고 성장할 수 있는지 확실히 확인해야 해요.
text_zh: 有个朋友给了我一个建议，我觉得对做领导来说特别棒。她跟我说："找工作的时候，要找那种你招进来的人能在那儿成就事业的地方。"我当时就想，哇，太对了。因为当时我手上有几个转型重组(turnaround)的工作机会，你觉得自己能搞定转型，那当然很好。但问题是，如果你要招最优秀的人才，你得确保这个地方对他们来说是个好平台，他们在这儿能学到东西，能成长起来。
text_es: Una amiga me dio un consejo que me pareció buenísimo como líder. Me dijo: "Acepta un trabajo donde, si contratas gente, les vayas a impulsar la carrera". Me quedé como "¡Órale!" Porque estaba recibiendo ofertas para algunos trabajos de reestructuración (turnaround). Y si crees que puedes darle la vuelta a la situación, perfecto. Pero si vas a contratar a los mejores, tienes que asegurarte de que va a ser un buen lugar para ellos, que van a aprender y van a crecer.
key_sentence: Take a job that will make their careers, not just a turnaround job.
